column1: maando-mba2018 156390393390 "2017-01-26 07:13:52 GMT" https://maando-mba2018.tumblr.com/post/156390393390/menloreads-muslims-and-the-making-of-america-by "menloreads: Muslims and the Making of Americaby Amir HussainCall number: E184 .M88 H87 2016 ‚ÄúThere has never been an America without Muslims""‚Äìso begins Amir Hussain
column2: one of the most important scholars and teachers of Islam in America. Hussain
column3: who is himself an American Muslim
column4: contends that Muslims played an essential role in the creation and cultivation of the United States. Memories of 9/11 and the rise of global terrorism fuel concerns about American Muslims. The fear of American Muslims in part stems from the stereotype that all followers of Islam are violent extremists who want to overturn the American way of life. Inherent to this stereotype is the popular misconception that Islam is a new religion in America. In¬†‚ÄúMuslims and the Making of America‚Äù Hussain directly addresses both of these stereotypes. Far from undermining America
column5: Islam and the American Muslims have been
column7: important threads in the fabric of American life. Hussain chronicles the history of Islam in America to underscore the valuable cultural influence of Muslims on American life. He then rivets attention on music
column9: and culture as key areas in which Muslims have shaped and transformed American identity. America
column11: would not exist as it does today without the essential contributions made by its Muslim citizens.   Dr. Amir Hussain is Professor of Theological Studies at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles
column12: where he teaches courses on world religions. His own particular speciality is the study of Islam
column13: focusing on contemporary Muslim societies in North America.¬† Table of Contents Introduction: The American ideal and Islam Islam in America: a short history Blues for Allah: music The greatest: sports Muslims on the American landscape: culture Conclusion: The poetry of ordinary American Muslim lives Includes bibliographical notes.   Selected by Cheryl Collins (ccollins@menlo.edu)  " False text
